DANIEL ROTHSCHILD: Thank you all for joining
us for what is sure to be an interesting event.

17.text:
The latest in our Conversations with Tyler
series with our special guest today, Professor

22.text:
Jeffrey Sachs from Columbia University.
The Mercatus Center is the world’s premier

28.text:
university-based resource for market-oriented
ideas. Our mission at the Mercatus Center

32.text:
is to bridge the gap between academic research
and real-world public policy questions in

38.text:
Washington, states, and local governments,
and indeed around the world.

41.text:
Today’s event is in aid of that. The Conversations
with Tyler series is all about bringing together

48.text:
world-class thought leaders who are thinking
big thoughts about important ideas for conversations

53.text:
with the general director of the Mercatus
Center.

55.text:
With that, it’s my pleasure to introduce
Tyler Cowen. Tyler is a Holbert L. Harris

61.text:
Chair in Economics at George Mason University.
He also, along with Alex Tabarrok, is a coblogger

66.text:
at marginalrevolution.com, one of the country’s
premier econ blogs, and with Alex, is the

74.text:
cocreator of Marginal Revolution University,
an innovative online platform for learning

79.text:
about and teaching economics.
For those of you who are readers of Marginal

83.text:
Revolution, as you already know, Tyler’s
interests are many and varied—which makes

87.text:
him the perfect host for this series. I don’t
know where he and Professor Sachs are going

92.text:
to go in their conversation today, but I’m
sure it’s going to be challenging. It’s

96.text:
going to be interesting. Above all, it’s
going to be smart.

99.text:
Again, on behalf of the Mercatus Center, thank
you all for joining us today. Please join

104.text:
me in welcoming Tyler Cowen and Jeffrey Sachs.
[applause]

113.text:
TYLER COWEN: I introduce Jeff Sachs; that’s
easy. Jeff is one of the world’s best, most

124.text:
famous, and most influential economists. There’s
more I could say, but let’s start with that.

130.text:
The purpose of these series is to have conversations
that you don’t find other places on YouTube,

135.text:
and to ask probing questions and have a far-ranging
dialogue. What I’d like to do is kind of

141.text:
overview of Jeff’s career and thought and
try and see how it all hangs together, how

146.text:
the different pieces relate to each other.
What I’d like to do is start with some of

150.text:
the early pieces, from the ’80s and 1990s.
Then we’ll work our way up to the present.

155.text:
The first question, Jeff, and we’ll treat
this as a dialogue. Some of your best-cited

159.text:
work has been on the natural resource curse:
the idea that economies, when they have natural

165.text:
resources—such as oil—that can harm their
prospects for growth rather than helping them.

170.text:
Now we’re in 2015. How do you see this issue
today? Do you think that has changed in any

176.text:
way since the first thesis you wrote?
JEFFREY SACHS: First, let me say thank you

181.text:
for having me. I’m really looking forward
to our discussion.

187.text:
About 25 years ago, I started looking more
and more at my own work and how economic structure,

194.text:
geography, resource base, and so forth affected
development. I’ve been on a learning curve

202.text:
since then. One of the early works that I
engaged in at that point with Andrew Warner

210.text:
and others was looking at this question of
how resource wealth, resource dependence one

217.text:
could say, affected development.
We found back in the 1990s, looking for the

224.text:
preceding 25 years or so, that the oil-rich
countries had grown less rapidly, controlling

232.text:
for seemingly other factors that would be
relevant. We started to speculate about that.

238.text:
There’s now a huge literature from many
different points of view: politics, pure economics,

247.text:
and so forth. It’s a pretty rich subject
and not so simple to summarize. There really

262.text:
is a resource curse for a lot of resource-rich
countries.

266.text:
At this point, looking back, I would put more
weight on the political economy aspects probably

275.text:
than the pure, market-driven “Dutch disease”
aspects which I talked about a quarter century

283.text:
ago. The idea at the time was that if you
have resource wealth that pulls you away from

291.text:
more labor-intensive and technology-intensive
industries. You don’t learn as much. You

298.text:
don’t develop as much endogenous growth.
Now I would say if you have resource wealth,

305.text:
one problem is you’re likely to be invaded.
You have more vulnerability to geopolitics

311.text:
as well as to internal politics to mess things
up.

315.text:
TYLER COWEN: Is this a habit you can kick
or is it path dependence? The price of oil

320.text:
now is quite low. Do you think those countries
that have a lot of oil, now they’re going

325.text:
to be better off because they’ll be put
on this new development path, or is it somehow

329.text:
too late, that they’re stuck with the bad
institutions?

331.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: First, one of the things that
I’ve tried to emphasize and that I’ve

338.text:
learned over time is it’s always pretty
complicated. There are resource-rich countries

344.text:
that do very well, thank you. There are resource-rich
countries that have fallen apart a long time

350.text:
ago and never gotten out of the mess. Any
generalization is fraught with problems.

357.text:
Norway will do well, whether the oil price
is high or low. On the other hand, last time

367.text:
the world oil price was persistently low,
the Soviet Union collapsed. Russia was near

376.text:
hyperinflation. Different countries under
different conditions will adjust to these

386.text:
shocks. Resource-rich Norway, Australia, Canada—I
wouldn’t worry too much about them.

394.text:
Their currencies will weaken. They will find
other things to do, whereas some of the very

402.text:
vulnerable countries that have never been
able to kick the habit of dependence, like

410.text:
Venezuela, will probably go into a deeper
crisis. The Middle East has been in flames

417.text:
now for years. I don’t see any easy way
out there, either.

420.text:
TYLER COWEN: Here’s the tension I’m trying
to figure out. It relates to a number of issues

425.text:
in your thought. You’ve written some very
interesting pieces lately about how the role

430.text:
of institutions is overrated in predicting
growth, but institutions seem to play a key

435.text:
role in making the resource theory stick.
As you say, Norway has done fine. The US in

441.text:
earlier times did fine with a lot of natural
resources.

444.text:
Does thinking about resources lead you back
to seeing institutions as important in some

450.text:
new and different way or are you still basically
skeptical about institutions mattering at

454.text:
all and wanting to look most of all to geography?
Do you see what I’m getting at?

459.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Of course, but again, I’ll
say it repeatedly, I’ve never said institutions

466.text:
don’t matter. I’ve said institutions aren’t
the only thing. I find often that people take

477.text:
an idea and carry it to an extreme.
This “institution matters” idea is one

485.text:
of those that I’ve found taken to extremes
by causing a kind of geographic blindness,

493.text:
if I could say it. Geography obviously matters
a lot. Resource base matters a lot. Institutions

498.text:
matter a lot. The world’s complex. We’re
dealing with complex systems.

503.text:
It’s not surprising that different things
matter at different times and different places.

508.text:
Of course, institutions make a difference.
The art of good economics, in my view, is

512.text:
trying to figure out what’s important, where,
when, and in which context.

516.text:
TYLER COWEN: Here’s a claim you’ve made.
It’s very striking. It’s one of the most

521.text:
important claims in development economics.
Personally, I think it’s true.

525.text:
When you reviewed Acemoglu and Robinson, you
said, “If we go to the year 1960, even knowing

530.text:
who the winners and losers have been, much
less forget about forecasting, it’s very

535.text:
hard to come up with a metric of institutions
that predicts which countries end up doing

541.text:
well and which countries end up doing poorly.”
When I read that, I tend to think somehow

547.text:
we’re mismeasuring institutional quality.
We really need a better measure of institutions,

552.text:
which we don’t have yet. Institutions will
someday matter again, but I’m looking for

557.text:
this in vain.
Where does your thought stand on this now?

560.text:
Do you actually think there’s some deeper
understanding of institutions that will rescue

564.text:
this proposition? When you throw out North
Korea and some other crazy countries, institutions

570.text:
don’t really have the predictive power for
growth.

573.text:
What are your thoughts on this, given that
in the across-country regressions, they can

577.text:
do so poorly within the set of semireasonable
countries?

580.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Acemoglu and Robinson’s book
Why Nations Fail was one of my least favorite

587.text:
books. I think it is just a bad book, because
it takes one thought and tries to drive it

595.text:
as the only explanation of history. That’s
not a good approach in my view to history,

604.text:
which is a very interesting, complex tableau.
They missed one fundamental point right from

612.text:
the start, which is that when you look at
development, there are at least two fundamental

619.text:
drivers, not just one. The one that they talk
about is innovation, and innovation as being

626.text:
a fundamental driver of growth. There’s
a lot of truth to that in the history of the

632.text:
world.
But there’s a second fundamental aspect

636.text:
when we look out in the world and say, “Who’s
doing well? Who’s doing badly? Why?” and

641.text:
so forth. That’s what is sometimes called
“catching up.” The phenomenon of catching

645.text:
up is very different from the phenomenon of
forging ahead at the front of the technology

654.text:
horizon.
When you take that simple distinction, it

661.text:
helps to explain a lot of the post-1960 question
that you’re asking. The most successful

668.text:
countries in the world in the last 50 years
have been basically the East Asian economies

675.text:
and Southeast Asian economies.
Very rarely do they look like the textbook

682.text:
model of Acemoglu and Robinson of the free
market economy and so forth. In fact, the

693.text:
People’s Republic of China they characterize
as just—that’s an anomaly that is going

699.text:
to collapse in the future so we don’t have
to explain it now.

702.text:
I think that’s a huge mistake and a misunderstanding
of the basics. China’s in a catching-up

707.text:
mode. The institutions of catching up are
quite different from the institutions of being

713.text:
the technology leader, for example. Just understanding
that would give them a little more clarity

720.text:
about institutions, per se.
TYLER COWEN: And corruption, over- or underrated

724.text:
as a driver of growth?
JEFFREY SACHS: It depends. Some places are

729.text:
so corrupt you first wouldn’t want to step
foot in them and I’ve had the experience

736.text:
repeatedly when I’m talking to a head of
state or a finance minister and I watch their

745.text:
eyes glaze over and realize they’re not
interested in what you’re talking about.

751.text:
They’re in a different game. Those places
can be driven absolutely into the ground by

759.text:
corruption.
Other places have been corrupt for a long

765.text:
time—I’m thinking of New York, Washington,
Lagos, Beijing, and other places—and you

776.text:
get a lot of economic progress. In that sense,
there is no purity in the world. I’m not

784.text:
a fan of corruption for a lot of reasons that
have started with the ethics.

788.text:
TYLER COWEN: China’s massively corrupt and
it’s growing at high rates, right?

793.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: China has a lot of corruption.
The first person to say it is President Xi.

800.text:
The US has a huge amount of corruption and
it has done reasonably well over the last

808.text:
200 years.
TYLER COWEN: Let me now ask you a question

811.text:
to challenge the audience, and we’re going
to turn to Paul Rosenstein-Rodan, who’s

815.text:
somewhat of a forgotten figure. But I think
still an important figure at George Mason,

820.text:
and maybe for you too.
As you know, Rosenstein-Rodan was a development

824.text:
economist. He was one of the pioneers of the
notion of the big push of an extended move

830.text:
forward on many fronts, all at the same time.
But when you look at the early years of his

835.text:
thought, he studied with Mises. He worked
with Hayek. He was an Austrian. He was a subjectivist,

841.text:
methodological individualist, and he made
some kind of theoretical shift in his mind.

847.text:
What is it that you think that Paul Rosenstein-Rodan
saw, and presumably you think you see it as

853.text:
well, that the people today who are still
Austrians at the theoretical level, what is

859.text:
it that Rosenstein-Rodan saw that allowed
him to make that shift or induced him to make

865.text:
that shift at the most basic conceptual level?
JEFFREY SACHS: He was writing during and at

871.text:
the end of World War II, when he was saying,
“How are we going to get out of this mess?

875.text:
There are so many pieces that have to be put
together. We have to get infrastructure built

879.text:
again. We have to get basic markets operating.
There are a lot of interconnected pieces,

887.text:
and so we’re going to have to move on a
lot of fronts.” He was facing a historical

891.text:
situation.
I would say that his idea—I’d go back

898.text:
even . . . actually, it’s not back. It was
almost contemporaneous with him. Alexander

903.text:
Gerschenkron, who was a very clever economic
historian at Harvard. I came as a student

914.text:
just as he was retiring. He was a great mid-century,
mid-20th century economic historian.

923.text:
He observed that what countries do for development
depends on how they stand in relation to the

932.text:
leader, and this is a point I was making earlier,
which is that catching up is a fundamental

940.text:
phenomenon in development.
There’s a difference of growth, which we

946.text:
study as an economy, how does it grow? From
the question of catching up, which is a question

954.text:
for a country that is situated with weak technology,
weak infrastructure, weak training, and so

961.text:
forth. In the face of advanced economies,
what should they do?

966.text:
Now that’s been a question that’s been
asked for at least 224 years, since Alexander

976.text:
Hamilton sent his letter to the congress on
manufacturing in the United States. Because

981.text:
he said we have to catch up with Britain.
Then Friedrich List said, “We have to catch

986.text:
up with Britain.” Economic reformers from
basically Hamilton on in countries that were

997.text:
lagging behind the lead said, “What do we
do to catch up?”

1001.text:
Now you can carry this too far because the
insane version of this, and the unbelievably

1007.text:
destructive version of this, was Lenin and
Stalin. We have to do anything at no matter

1012.text:
what cost of life to catch up, or Mao in the
Great Leap Forward, which is insanity and

1019.text:
cruelty.
But, on the other hand, the idea that you

1022.text:
do different things to catch up by accelerating
the process or by making the big push in a

1030.text:
variety of ways has been shown time and again
to have a lot of merit. It’s a balance,

1037.text:
once more. The first countries to develop,
Britain and the United States . . . Take the

1042.text:
US. We’ve achieved almost continuous 1.8
percent per year per capita growth for the

1049.text:
last 200 years. Not bad, if you do it for
200 years.

1054.text:
But if you’re an impoverished country today
and you say, “What’s our aim? 1.8 percent

1059.text:
growth?” No, our aim is 10 percent growth,
because we really need to catch up. It turned

1066.text:
out, because of that catching-up phenomenon,
you can make a very, very rapid advance in

1073.text:
a way unthinkable for a country in front.
But how do you make that advance? Through

1080.text:
pure government just stepping back and letting
things happen? No. Through a concerted policy

1088.text:
to close gaps. That’s the difference.
TYLER COWEN: I’ve been reviewing your work,

1093.text:
including these books, and a stack of papers
here, which is a small fraction of what you’ve

1100.text:
written. I believe they all have your name
on them. What I try to do with thinkers sometimes

1105.text:
is boil down what they’ve been writing to
the smallest number of dimensions possible.

1110.text:
If you’ll bear with me for a moment, I’m
going to try to do that with you, and then

1114.text:
you tell me where I’m off, or what you would
add to that. Reviewing all the things you’ve

1119.text:
written . . .
JEFFREY SACHS: You probably know more about

1121.text:
me than I do, so let’s see how it goes.
[laughter]

1124.text:
TYLER COWEN: Maybe. But there are two phrases
that strike me again and again. One is when

1128.text:
you mention your wife, Sonia, and talk about
differential diagnostics. The other is what

1133.text:
you call the epoch of the Anthropocene, which
you could think of as the time when human

1139.text:
beings are in the world in an active way.
When we start with primitive society, everything

1146.text:
is determined by geography and resources.
Economic development, in a sense, is an ongoing

1153.text:
process where human beings impose their will
and their reason on the world in a kind of

1160.text:
planning or voluntaristic fashion.
Then there’s a belief that first this needs

1166.text:
to be done in a differential way. Not the
same recipe everywhere. But a belief in the

1172.text:
power of human reason to perform these differential
diagnostics to turn this era when humans are

1178.text:
on the earth into a time when we’re no longer
ruled by resources and geography and the prevalence

1184.text:
of malaria. But brought into an era where
human reason is in some sense running the

1189.text:
show.
If I had to boil down my reread of you into

1193.text:
a very short bulletin, that’s what I would
say. Now do you agree with that, how would

1198.text:
you change it, and what would you add to that?
JEFFREY SACHS: That’s pretty good, first

1202.text:
of all. I would subscribe to that summary.
I should explain this idea of clinical economics,

1213.text:
as I’ve called it, or differential diagnosis.
When you’re married to a pediatrician, as

1218.text:
I have been for 35 wonderful years, you get
up in the middle of the night a lot when patients

1226.text:
call with a very sick child.
I’ve listened to my wife take an oral history

1230.text:
a thousand—thousands of times, perhaps.
It’s a wonderful art, first of all, because

1243.text:
a mother calls with a crisis of a baby or
a young child—usually a high fever. The

1252.text:
first thing that is important to know is that
there are a thousand possible etiologies of

1258.text:
that fever. My wife doesn’t say institutions.
She says . . .

1267.text:
hear your problem. Oh, you’re in a desert,
you’re here, you’re this . . .” No,

1277.text:
when it comes to the child, it could be something
as normal as a common cold or a something

1285.text:
as devastating as meningitis.
The purpose of a differential diagnosis is

1293.text:
two things. First, it is of course to try
to get to the core reasons so that you can

1303.text:
make a proper prescription based on a proper
diagnosis. Second, it’s done in a way that

1310.text:
you’re minimizing serious risk.
The first question always that my wife asks

1317.text:
is, “Is the baby’s neck stiff, or do you
notice that?” Because that’s one of the

1322.text:
symptoms of meningitis. If the mother answers
that way, the next point is “I’ll meet

1332.text:
you at the emergency room. Don’t stop. Just
go.” Because it could be something that

1337.text:
is fulminant and life-threatening immediately.
If it’s not that, then it can go on for

1342.text:
an hour.
But by the way, it’s not just an hour of

1346.text:
questions. It’s an hour of sequenced questions
down a decision tree, and it’s fascinating

1350.text:
to watch. I wish as economists we had those
basic skills inbred. I certainly didn’t

1357.text:
learn them, and it took me a long time of
seeing lots of “patients” to see that

1363.text:
one needs that same kind of approach.
That’s what I mean by differential diagnosis.

1369.text:
Why it’s so annoying to me, the one explanation
fits all viewpoints. Because now I’ve seen

1377.text:
a lot of places, a lot of crises, a lot of
challenges. One of the things that I discovered

1385.text:
was how poor our profession is at times in
having that sense that the problem that you

1395.text:
saw over there is not the same as the problem
that you’re seeing here.

1399.text:
TYLER COWEN: Let me push on this a bit and
see if you can convert me into being more

1405.text:
of a Sachsian. One of my worries is that the
doctors are not actually in charge. It may

1410.text:
be the lawyers, which is . . . We’re in
a law school, but still, if I may say, in

1414.text:
some ways a step down.
To some extent you have people voting on the

1419.text:
baby, not all of whom even know who the baby
is or what the baby’s symptoms are. The

1426.text:
differential diagnostics may exist in a kind
of platonic realm, but you are more optimistic

1432.text:
about them than I am.
What would you tell me to address my skepticism

1437.text:
and make me more of a Sachsian, given that
I have this reluctance to embrace your view

1442.text:
the way you hold it?
JEFFREY SACHS: I think I get what you’re

1446.text:
driving at and I do have a fundamental view
of at least how I want to proceed professionally.

1455.text:
But it’s also based a bit on a theory of
change.

1461.text:
TYLER COWEN: Tell us the theory.
JEFFREY SACHS: I believe that knowledge matters

1467.text:
and that the more clarity, the more evidence,
the more appropriate an analysis, the more

1481.text:
likely we can find a good outcome to things.
Many people are cynical. I tend not to be.

1493.text:
I’m sometimes accused of being gullible
as a result, or being too soft in the face

1498.text:
of whatever. But I believe that there’s
a way to reach an agreement, typically, among

1510.text:
pretty conflictual and often pretty antagonistic
actors.

1515.text:
I tend to believe there’s a way out of a
crisis, and I tend to believe that a lot of

1520.text:
what poses as either pure zero-sum struggle
or harsh ideological conflict is often resolvable

1535.text:
by good, clear ideas, or good, clear evidence,
or a good, clear game plan.

1540.text:
TYLER COWEN: So you’re very optimistic about
the power of human reason?

1544.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: I believe that’s where we
should put our bets.

1547.text:
TYLER COWEN: That’s a different claim. See,
I believe we should put our bets on human

1551.text:
reason. It’s all we have. But I’m not
necessarily that . . .

1554.text:
JEFFREY SACHS: Then we don’t have to even
disagree, because we’re going to act the

1557.text:
same way.
TYLER COWEN: Let me mention this book. Reading

1560.text:
this book, it really cleared up for me, I
think, a lot of the things you believe. It’s

1564.text:
called To Move the World: JFK’s Quest for
Peace. It came out last year. It’s received

1569.text:
attention, but less so from economists, for
obvious reasons.

1572.text:
It’s a book about leaders sitting down and
just doing something and basically getting

1578.text:
it right. Is that fair to say? Solving—more
or less solving the Cuban Missile Crisis,

1583.text:
defusing tensions, avoiding nuclear war, right?
JEFFREY SACHS: It’s a book, yes, of this

1591.text:
remarkable last year of Kennedy’s life,
which included the Cuban Missile Crisis and

1598.text:
then negotiating the partial nuclear test
ban treaty. Basically, I find it a story of

1609.text:
tremendous insight and very moving also. If
I could put it in pure conceptual jargon,

1618.text:
it’s a story of finding a way to the cooperative
outcome of a prisoner’s dilemma.

1625.text:
That’s, to my mind, a crucial structural
feature of our lives, which is that we face

1633.text:
constantly this challenge of finding agreement.
We face constantly the logic of defection,

1644.text:
as it’s called in the prisoner’s dilemma,
or the noncooperative outcome that’s worse

1649.text:
for everybody.
The question is what to do about that. The

1656.text:
cynics say, “Well, the world’s bound to
disagree.” The idealists say, “The world

1667.text:
will always agree, or we should always act
that way.” I find fascinating and compelling

1676.text:
the idea that we should try to find ways to
move to cooperation, knowing how fragile that

1685.text:
is.
TYLER COWEN: This story, it really fits your

1687.text:
model of change. That’s why, reading the
book, it was like a lightbulb went off in

1691.text:
my head.
JEFFREY SACHS: For me, it also went off in

1695.text:
my head as I learned more about this, which
is that Kennedy and Khrushchev stumbled into

1705.text:
nearly the end of the world in October of
1962, and Kennedy made his share of terrible

1715.text:
mistakes. Our USG, which I’m usually not
